div.p: THE LAMENTATION OF The Safe Committee.
OR, Fleetwood's Teares, Hewſon's Laſt, Deſborough's Cart, Met together at Hangmans-FAYRE. WITH Their Neck-verſes, and ſeverall Diſcourſes thereon.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: YOur moſt humble ſervant Col. Hewſon.

sp.speaker: Hew.
sp.p: A poor Cobler thanks you ſir: but I have been your ſervant too long for my profit as it falls out now.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why Col. Hewſon what miſchief ſoever you have done for me and my brethren I believe you have had your deſerts fort

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No not ſo neither Sir, for if I had I'd been hangd at Wallingford Houſe a twelvemonth a goe.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why? I hope you never loſt by me Coll. Hewſon?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I am ſure I never got by ye, except twas ſhame, reproach, and ignominy.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Truly Coll. Hewſon 'twas even ſuch as I had my ſelf, therefore be content, for what the Divil ſent me, even ſuch take you and be thankfull.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Thankfull! for what Mr. Fleetwood?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
For the Commiſſion you tooke of me at
Wallingford Houſe laſt winter, when you went into the Citty and kild a prentice boy, whereby you got your honour.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Tooke a Commiſſion of you then, the Divil pick your bones; I would I had took a Coblers ſtalle at that time, 'twould have ſaved me the price of my Neck I am ſure on't.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: No, no Coll. Hewſon the old proverb ſes, 'tis craft un the catching; and you are ſafe yet.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Oh las Mr. Fleetwood you talke, know ye not the Fox is craftier then all Beaſts, yet he is hunted by the ſcent of his ſizling Taile, that through his loathſomeneſſe he is catcht at laſt.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What, then you thinke the odiouſneſſe of our action, will cauſe all people to hunt after us?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Aye, and all the world will endeavour to take us.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But how will they know us Brother Hewſon?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O too well Brother Fleetwood, I by my blind eye, which now might wiſh I never had any at all. And you by your long ſpare necke, I would a had been hang'd twenty years agoe, then we had quit all theſe calamities,

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I could ſay ſo to Brother Hewſon, and wiſh as the Scripture ſaith; That a Milſtone had been hang'd about my Neck and that I had been caſt in the bottome of the Sea, before I had been plung'd in all theſe ſorrows; and the Scripture ſaith, Yet they are but the beginning of Sorows.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Brother Fleetwood, you were ever prone ſo to Scripture Language, that the Divil a good word proceeded fron your mouth at laſt.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why Brother Hewſon, I thought you to be a downright deſtroyer, Tranſlator of Religion, as you were formerly of Boots and Shooes.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
Aye Brother Fleetwood, 'twas better then go through ſtitch, then now through Treaſon, I was tearmed then an honeſt Cobler, now cald an arrand Traitor; but the Divil bewitcht you to ſtir up ſmoake from quenched flames, in ſending me with my poor reprobates many wanting Hoſe and Shooes, into the awakned City, where we ſeemed unto them like ſo many Sprights, or as a wodden packſaddle on a galld horſe bach, ſpurning, kicking, and ſpitting at us; ſo theſe wrought
our diſtruction.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p:
Nay but Brother Hewſon, I thought to Reforme Religion, and promote the An •
baptiſts, which promiſed me great ſums of Money.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: O you ſhould have tooke the Money, by all meanes in the world; and let them been hang'd.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Faith that had been the beſt way Brother Hewſon, but now I fear we ſhall be hang'd, therefore prepare your ſelf.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Prepare my ſelf brother Fleetwood, truly I believe the whole Kingdome can teſtifie, that we were ready for't a Dozen Years agoe.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: But I tould you often times and ſeverally, not to plunge your ſoft braine of deſtruction, in the ruines of Religion, but reſt quietly in your den of ſedition, eating up the fat of the Land, and reaping the fruits of other mens benefits; and was not this a brave, ſweete, Jewiſh, heritical life for us two to a liv'd in?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p:
Aye truely brother, but in thoſe dayes I did not much liſten to ye, for my heart was waxed groſſe, and my eares were dull of hearing, my tongue was full of deceite, and my hands were full of cheating, and truly
I thought to adminiſter and execute injuſtice and Deſtruction impartially, throughout the whole Kingdome, till my ſeditions began to depart from me, and that Sea Monſter appeared out of Scotland.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Out of Scotland do ye ſay? you know very well that we had as active Idolizing hipocrites, in Scotland and Ireland, both for fraud and confuſion as we our ſelves were, had they but obeyed our Speciall Commands.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Well brother Hewſon, we had Diviliſh failings in altering our Church Government.

sp.speaker: H:
sp.p: Aye brother Fleetwood ſo we had, but for good ſums of money we would have endeavoured too, to have altered the foundation of England.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why, would you have ventured the other eye for it?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Aye Faith brother that I wo'd, both body and ſoule, I love Money ſo well.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But what Churches would you have had then?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Churches, none at all, did not I forewarn you alwaies not to meddle with Church government.

sp.speaker: F:
sp.p:
Why brother Hewſon, did you ſee me
meddle with the government to promote it? Indeed I muſt confeſſe, the Churches I would have pul'd down as faſt as I dould; But for worſhip, I did in my Den, like a Hog in his ſtye, you know very well I never ſtir'd a foote out of dores.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But did you thinke of no Religion then Brother Hewſon?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: No as god judge my Soule brother Fleetwood, no more then I did of my dying day.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What, were you led by the Spirit altogether?

sp.speaker: H:
sp.p: Yes truly, but I had Divliſh faylings.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But what makes that terrible ſhaking in your head, and your left hand?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why truly that come of a Dreame two yeares agoe, for I thought the King was coming home, and with the affright the very horrour of my conſcience fum'd up into my head, whereby it continued ever ſince.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: But what Action were you imployed in brother Hewſon, when you loſt that eye?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
O brother Fleetwood when I loſt that eye, wod both yours had dropt out, then the Nation had been a great dale
the better for't, and we might have kept our heads on, which now lies in a dangerous quere:

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why, will they head us de'e think?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Head us, or Hang us, it's all one to them.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Aye but Dun will not do it I am ſure out. Oh brother 'tis ſorry truſting him, for he has hang'd many a one for leſſe cauſe, I'le warrant ye.

lg.head: Neck-Verſe.
lg.l: THen come thou noble handed Blade,
Since fortune proved, ſuch a jade;
I muſt ſubmit to thee.
Though once I thought I never ſhould
Be ſubiect to a King,
When like to Nero I did rule,
I was more Lord then him.
I thought I was the beſt of Men
And all the people knew,
An Oracle I ſeemed then,
To my ſeditious crew.
My actions baſe and infinite
And to the world is known,
But all the joyes I have in it
I ſhall not die alone.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Dye alone brother Fleetwood, no, no, ther's a hundred, and a hundred, will be hanged biſides you and I.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: O it may be you do meane the Rump, but they were not above fourſcore.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Aye, but when they and we come together, we make a Diveliſh number.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why then the Divil was in them as well as we?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Aye brother that ye may be ſure on, for he was no reſpecter of perſons.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: I would he had run us into the middle of the Sea then, as he did the Hearde of Swine.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nay brother Fleetwood, he had rather run us to be hang'd firſt I doubt, he owed us a ſhame and we ſhall fully be payed it.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Oh but alas, here comes my brother Desborough; your moſt humble ſervant Coll. Desborough.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: A Colonel, a Hang-man.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why a Hang-man brother Desbrough?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: It's better be a hang-man, then to be hang'd my ſelf.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Come, come, brother Desbrough, lets beare good Cheere as long as we are alive.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Aye and that's impoſſible it ſhould be long.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Then let us go to prayers a little.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Aye as little as you pleaſe, for I could never pray in all my life.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: What ſay you brother Hewſon?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why truly I ſay thus, I have no more patience to pray, then I have to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Alas deare brethren I cannot blame ye.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly brother, a great many do, though they do not.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why, whats the newes, in thoſe parts you have been?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Nothing but noiſe over all the Countries roaring in the vallies, like huntſ men after wolves, and all their Cry is, Fleetwood, Desbrough, and Hewſon.

sp.speaker: F:
sp.p: Why, do they know that we are in the Country?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Aye, as well as you your ſelves do.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: O ſad newes, ſad newes, but what do they call us?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Call us, they terme us to be Vagabonds, Runagades, and Fugatives, bearing the marke of the beaſt, and the curſe of Cain; threatning every one that meet, us to ſlay us,

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Alas a day, and how come you ſo ſafe hither?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Truly with much adoe, a greater hazard then I was in at the takeing of Tredath in Ireland.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Why, did they ever atttempt upon ye?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O ſeveral times, and once I was faine to leape into a houſe of office, and there I kept my office above a quarter of an houre; receiving ſuch a ſcent, enough to Raviſh any Carre Horſe in London, but being but counterfeit attempt, I retired to the houſe againe, thinking to ſhift my all ſcented garment; the woman of the houſe bid me be gone for a ſtinking knave or elſe ſhe'd fetch the Conſtable, which I had rather a heard talke of the Divil at that time, and ſo I tript over the plaine, with all the dogs in the town after me.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: Alas deare brother, thou haſt been perſecuted as well as I: Pray whats yours? Truly when I forſooke London, I was dreſt in a poore gray ſuit, and I went intoSurry, where neare unto Darkin, as I was going over a Stile an unmannerly Spill catcht me by the poore conditioned Breetches and ript them up to the waſte, which made me tripp two miles out of my way to have them repaired.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: But whether was the Spirit leading you then?

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: My intended place was to Hampſhire, to meete with ſome of my brother Traytors, but fortune not much favouring us, I deſigned my purpoſe, hither to Lanceſton.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: O brother Fleetwood, I cannot chooſe but think what a Divliſh fate have hang'd over our heads, ever ſince our Grand Sire Nol took's leave.

sp.speaker: F.
sp.p: O aye brother Desbrough in his daies we behaved our ſelves like three ſtout, valiant Divils, which cauſed us ſtill to have Diviliſh fortune, but now let us ſit down and ſay on this manner.

lg.l: O Fortune why haſt thou beguiled me?
Which in thy boſome alwaies did me Nurſe,
Could'ſt thou not find no other plagues for me
but this to make me only be accurſt;
Which is in Scripture written plaine you ſee,
Cur'ſt is the man that hangeth on a tree.
I poore blind Hewſon, Cobler am by Trade,
A Coll: once though now have got a fall,
My actions are rechoded good and bad,
Which will appeares in publicke to you all.
And in the lines you plainly there might read,
A prentice boy in London Murdered.
I Coll. Desbrough formerly a Lord,
Which Title ſeemed to me moſt unfit;
Created by the Divel and the Sword,
And in high courts of Juſtice I did ſit,
Nor doth my bloody acts make me diſpaire
For in the Gallows I do claime my ſhare.
